item.title: Contact a Librarian
item.description: $(document).ready(function(e){$('#s-la-askform-submit-21757').click(function(e){$('div.preloader-wrapper').show();$.ajax({url:"https://api2.libanswers.com/1.0/form/submit",data:$('#s-la-askform-form_21757').serialize(),success:function(d){$('div#result').html(''+d.message+' ');$('div.preloader-wrapper').hide();},type:'POST',dataType:'json'}).fail(function(){$('div.preloader-wrapper').hide();$('div#result').html('Error: Please try again ');});});});    Subject Content Email (Required) Name Submit Administration Dalia Corkrum, College Librarian — 509-527-5193 Kathleen Hutchison, Administrative Assistant — 509-527-5191 Archives and Special Collections Ben Murphy, Archivist and Special Collections Librarian — 509-526-4731

item.title: About the Library
item.description: Penrose Library: An Educational Partner Penrose Library fosters the intellectual engagement and scholarly practice of the Whitman community. We curate and provide access to diverse and unique collections, and teach the skills and concepts needed to navigate complex information environments at Whitman and beyond. Penrose Library has been consistently highly ranked by the Princeton Review.

item.title: Explore our Collections
item.description: Collection Areas Northwest Manuscripts Collection WCNA acknowledges that we exist upon the traditional homeland of the Cayuse, Umatilla, Walla Walla and Nez Perce Peoples. WCNA collects and solicits donations of manuscripts and records from individuals and organizations of significance to the history and present of the Walla Walla region and the inland Pacific Northwest.

item.title: Faculty Services
item.description: In brief, Top 10 Things for Faculty to know about Penrose Library Library Instruction As detailed in the Penrose Library Mission and Guiding Principles and our teaching philosophy and learning goals, the Instructional and Research Services department guides students through the research process, helping them develop critical thinking skills to conduct research, synthesize information, and communicate the results of intellectual inquiry.

item.title: Information for Researchers
item.description: Reading Room Procedures The Reading Room is open to the public from 9am-4pm, Monday through Friday. Appointments are encouraged, but not required. Appointments can be made by emailing archives@whitman.edu or calling 509-527-5922. The following guidelines are required for all patrons working in the Reading Room:

item.title: Instruction and Tours
item.description: Class Sessions in the Archives Faculty are encouraged to incorporate materials from the Archives into their teaching. There are multiple, scalable options for curricular use of collections and the Archivists are available to work with you to achieve your pedagogical goals. These include: A single class visit to the archives to orient students to the collections and space A thematic visit to the archives, with selections on a particular topic, subject, or theme An assignment designed around collections that requires out-of-class student visits to the archives An entire class or syllabus built around archival collections In all these scenarios, our instruction focuses both on enabling students to find and use collections, and developing their skills in analyzing and interpreting primary sources.

item.title: Journal Finder
item.description: Find a Journal by title e-Journal A-Z List Contains Exact phrase Begins with Journal title Search Omit initial articles such as "the," "a," "le"... Find an Article by Title Article title Search Find an Article by Citation Article Title: Journal title Author Last Name: Author First Name: Date (YYYY-MM-DD): Volume Issue Start page ISSN PMID DOI Search $(document).

item.title: Library Services
item.description: Search Library FAQ In brief, Top 10 Things for Students to Know about Penrose Library. Borrow & Request Penrose Library extends borrowing privileges to all Whitman College students, faculty, and staff members. Although the Library’s primary commitment is to members of the Whitman community, certain library privileges are available to visiting scholars, local high school students, and members of the general public.
